clinical_study.brief_title: 5 Year Registry Study to Track Clinical Application of DecisionDx-UM Assay Results and Associated Patient Outcomes
clinical_study.official_title: CLEAR Registry Study: An Open, 5-year Registry Study to Track Clinical Application of DecisionDx-UM Multigene Assay Results and Associated Patient Outcomes.

brief_summary.textblock: Uveal Melanoma is a rare cancer with approximately 3,000 cases diagnosed in the US every year. Nearly half of these experience spread of their cancer outside the eye. The DecisionDx-UM gene expression test classifies an individual's tumor as low risk (class 1) or high risk (class 2) of spreading. This study is being done to collect information about how physicians are using the DecisionDx-UM results to design individual treatment plans. It will also track outcomes or the uveal melanoma population that received DecisionDx-UM testing.

primary_outcome.measure: documentation of clinical application of results obtained from DecisionDx-UM multi-gene assay
primary_outcome.time_frame: Approximately 3-6 weeks after biopsy of uveal tumor
primary_outcome.description: Physician treatment plan with regards to surveillance regimen as well as treatment referral pattern

primary_outcome.time_frame: Patients followed for up to 10 years, measurement for metastatic event performed at 6 month intervals

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients followed for up to 10 years at 6 month intervals
secondary_outcome.description: review of health care testing (imaging, laboratory testing) to determine changes in health care costs resulting from DecisionDx-UM testing

study_pop.textblock: Patients diagnosed with uveal melanoma and determined by their treating physician to be appropriate for DecisionDx-UM testing.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with a diagnosis of Uveal Melanoma
- Patients whose physician deems them appropriate for DecisionDx-UM testing
- Patients reasonably able to follow up with enrolling physician at regular intervals for assessment of outcome data
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with any other form of cancer
